questions.text: Injury at which of the following marked sites causes failure of dorsiflexion?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 3

 

The site marked as '3' in the x-ray given above is the neck of the fibula. Injury at this site causes failure of dorsiflexion (foot drop) due to injury to the common fibular nerve.

 

Neck of Fibula is the narrowed region just distal to the head of the fibula. The common fibular (peroneal) nerve winds around the neck of the fibula. This makes the nerve vulnerable at this site, and any injury or compression can affect nerve function.

 

Site 1 – Lateral epicondyle

 

Site 2 – Head of Fibula

 

Site 3 – Neck of Fibula

 

Site 4 – Tibia

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Site 1. Lateral Epicondyle: It is a prominent bony protrusion on the lateral side of the distal end of the humerus, which is the bone of the upper arm. "Tennis elbow" or lateral epicondylitis is a common condition associated with the lateral epicondyle. It's caused by overuse and inflammation of the tendons that attach to the lateral epicondyle, leading to pain and tenderness at the site.

 

Site 2 - Head of Fibula: It is the proximal, rounded end of the fibula, the smaller of the two leg bones. It's located just below the lateral aspect of the knee joint.

 

This is the location of the common fibular (peroneal) nerve, which wraps around the neck of the fibula. Injuries or fractures to the head of the fibula may damage this nerve, potentially leading to foot drop.

 

Site 4 - Tibia: It is also known as the shinbone, is the larger, medial, and anterior bone of the leg, located between the knee and the ankle. It is anteromedially placed in the leg and is palpable along its length. The tibia is a common site for fractures, especially the distal part, due to its subcutaneous position. The anterior surface of the tibia, known as the shin, is easily palpable and is often the site of contusions or "shin splints" in athletes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common fibular nerve's course around the neck of the fibula makes this area a hotspot for injuries leading to dorsiflexion failure, underlining the importance of protecting this area from trauma.

questions.text:
Consider the following actions under AMTSL. Arrange them in the right order? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Uterine tone assessment
  2. Give uterotonic (oxytocin 10 mg)
  3. Exclude the presence of another fetus
  4. Controlled cord traction

 

AMTSL- Active management of the third stage of labor.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3, 2, 4, 1

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) is a set of interventions aimed at preventing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). The correct order of actions is:

 

3. Exclude the presence of another fetus: Ensure there is no additional fetus before administering any uterotonic.

 

2. Give uterotonic (oxytocin 10 mg): Administer a uterotonic drug to help the uterus contract and reduce bleeding. It is given after the delivery of baby.

 

4. Controlled cord traction: Perform controlled traction on the umbilical cord to deliver the placenta.

 

1. Uterine tone assessment: assess the uterine tone every 15 minutes to detect uterine atony.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The steps of Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) should be followed in a specific order: exclude the presence of another fetus, administer a uterotonic, perform controlled cord traction, and then assess the uterine tone.

choices.text: Knuckle bender splint; Ulnar Nerve Palsy
Dynamic cock up splint; Radial Nerve Palsy
Turn buckle splint; Volkmann’s Ischemic Contracture
Knuckle bender splint; Median Nerve Palsy

questions.text: Correctly match the statement regarding the splint shown in image:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dynamic cock up splint; Radial Nerve Palsy

 

  • Cock-up splint is used for radial nerve palsy.

 

 

RADIAL NERVE INJURIES

 

  • Most common nerve damaged in human body.
  • Most common cause: Fracture of shaft of Humerus
  • Shaft of Humerus divided into 3 parts:
    • Upper 1/3rd
    • Middle 1/3rd
    • Lower 1/3rd: Radial nerve injured (50%)
       
  • Holstein Lewis sign: Radial nerve injury in lower 1/3rd fracture of shaft of Humerus
  • Paralysis of ECRL & ECRB will cause loss of wrist, thumb and finger extension, leading to Wrist drop.
  • Wrist drop occurs in low radial nerve palsy, which spares the elbow and wrist extension.
  • There is also loss of sensation over the dorsum of 1st web space.

 

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment is usually conservative, which includes analgesic medications like NSAIDs; corticosteroid injections; physiotherapy; and immobilization with cock-up splints for 2-4 weeks.
    • The patient recovers within 4 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knuckle bender splint; Ulnar nerve palsy. Knuckle bender splint is a finger flexion splint which flexes the MCP joint of all digits without blocking the IP joint or wrist joint motion. it assists the intrinsic muscle weakness. It is used in cases ulnar nerve palsy (ulnar claw hand) and median nerve palsy.

 

 

Option C. Turn buckle splint; Volkmann’s ischemic contracture. Turn buckle splint is used to produce gradual stretching over the contracted joint. It is used to treat stiff elbow and Volkmann’s ischemic contracture.

 

 

Option D. Knuckle bender splint; Median nerve palsy. Knuckle bender splint is a finger flexion splint which flexes the MCP joint of all digits without blocking the IP joint or wrist joint motion. it assists the intrinsic muscle weakness. It is used in cases ulnar nerve palsy (ulnar claw hand) and median nerve palsy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question is a dynamic cock-up splint, which is used in cases of radial nerve injuries (wrist drop).

questions.text: Which receptor helps in improvement of insulin resistance in Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus with regular exercise and physical activity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GLUT4

 

GLUT4 is a glucose transporter found primarily in adipose tissues and striated muscles (skeletal and cardiac). It is insulin-dependent, meaning its activity increases in response to insulin. During exercise, the translocation of GLUT4 to the cell membrane is stimulated, enhancing glucose uptake into cells even in the absence of insulin. This mechanism is crucial in improving insulin sensitivity and combating insulin resistance, particularly in individuals with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM2). Regular physical activity enhances this effect, leading to better glucose control and reduction of hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GLUT1: This glucose transporter is found in many tissues, including the brain, and is responsible for basal glucose uptake. It is not significantly influenced by insulin and does not play a direct role in improving insulin resistance in DM2.

 

Option C. GLUT2: GLUT2 is primarily found in the liver, pancreas, kidneys, and intestines. It functions in glucose sensing and plays a role in glucose homeostasis but is not directly involved in the insulin-dependent improvement of glucose uptake seen in DM2.

 

Option D. GLUT3: GLUT3 is a high-affinity glucose transporter found predominantly in neurons. It ensures a constant supply of glucose to the brain, but it is not insulin-dependent and does not have a significant role in the management of insulin resistance in DM2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT4 is the insulin-dependent glucose transporter that plays a key role in improving insulin resistance with regular exercise and physical activity.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient happens to have pellagra-like eruptions on skin in spring season from the last 5 years with normal HIAA and high aminoaciduria. Indole levels in urine are normal. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hartnup disease

 

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a defect in the absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids in the intestine and renal tubules. This defect leads to increased excretion of amino acids in the urine, known as aminoaciduria. Tryptophan is a precursor for niacin (Vitamin B3) synthesis, and its deficiency can lead to pellagra-like symptoms, including dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, often referred to as the "3 D's" of pellagra.

 

In this case, the patient presents with pellagra-like eruptions and high aminoaciduria. The normal HIAA levels rule out a carcinoid tumor, which would show elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine due to increased serotonin production. The absence of dietary history indicative of niacin or tryptophan deficiency (as seen in nutritional pellagra) further supports Hartnup disease as the diagnosis. Additionally, essential fructosuria is a benign condition and does not cause skin eruptions or pellagra-like symptoms.

 

Note –

 

  • Tryptophan is an aromatic amino acid with a bulky indole ring side chain.
  • 60 mg of tryptophan converts into 1 mg of niacin
  • Best Treatment of Niacin deficiency - Niacin or nicotinamide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid tumor: Carcinoid syndrome would typically present with elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine due to excessive conversion of tryptophan to serotonin. The normal HIAA levels in this patient make carcinoid tumor an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option B. Nutritional pellagra: This condition is due to a dietary deficiency of niacin (Vitamin B3) or its precursor tryptophan. However, the patient does not present with a history of dietary deficiency, and the high aminoaciduria suggests an alternative diagnosis.

 

Option D. Essential fructosuria: This condition is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme fructokinase, leading to fructose excretion in urine. However, it is asymptomatic and does not cause skin eruptions or any pellagra-like symptoms, making it an incorrect answer in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pellagra or pellagra like symptoms can result from (Differential Diagnosis):

 

  • Niacin (B3) deficiency due to a diet high in maize, which is low in tryptophan.
  • Vitamin B6 deficiency, since the enzyme kynureninase, which catalyzes a step in niacin synthesis from tryptophan, requires B6 as a cofactor. B6 deficiency also leads to increased synthesis of xanthurenic acid
  • Carcinoid syndrome: can be differentiated with elevated HIAA level with pellagra like symptoms.
  • Hartnup disease can present with pellagra-like symptoms due to defective absorption of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids, leading to high aminoaciduria and niacin deficiency.

questions.text: A neonate was brought with complaints of poor feeding, vomiting, acidosis, and cataract. Urine Benedict’s test was positive, while urine glucose was negative. The enzyme defective in this case is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

 

The symptoms described—poor feeding, vomiting, acidosis, cataract, and a positive Benedict’s test with negative urine glucose—are characteristic of classical galactosemia, a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. This enzyme is crucial in the metabolism of galactose, a sugar found in milk and dairy products. When this enzyme is deficient, galactose-1-phosphate accumulates in tissues, leading to toxic effects including liver damage, cataract formation (oil drop cataract), and intellectual disability due to energy deficiency in the brain.

 

The positive Benedict’s test indicates the presence of a reducing sugar, which in this case is galactose, not glucose, explaining the negative glucose test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fructokinase: This enzyme is involved in fructose metabolism, specifically converting fructose to fructose-1-phosphate. Its deficiency leads to essential fructosuria, a benign and asymptomatic condition that does not cause the symptoms observed in this case.

 

Option B. Sucrase: Sucrase breaks down sucrose into glucose and fructose. Sucrase deficiency primarily causes gastrointestinal symptoms like bloating, gas, and diarrhea after consuming sucrose (common in sugarcane juice). It is unrelated to the clinical presentation described.

 

Option D. Lactase: Lactase is responsible for the digestion of lactose into glucose and galactose. Its deficiency causes lactose intolerance, characterized by diarrhea, gas, and abdominal pain after consuming dairy, but does not lead to acidosis or cataract formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classical galactosemia is caused by a deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, leading to the accumulation of galactose and its metabolites, resulting in serious clinical symptoms including cataracts and liver damage.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the treatment of a patient who presented with the following as shown in the image? Earlier the abdominal mass was reducible, but now it has become irreducible. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Umbilical excision with herniorrhaphy

 

The clinical scenario presented is that of an umbilical hernia that was previously reducible but has now become irreducible. This suggests the hernia has become complicated, possibly due to incarceration or strangulation, where the contents are trapped, leading to ischemia or gangrene of the herniated tissue. The overlying skin also appears gangrenous and requires excision.

 

The correct management involves surgical intervention to excise the affected umbilical tissue and perform herniorrhaphy, which is a repair of the hernia without the use of a mesh, particularly when there are complications such as strangulation or infection. The surgical approach must address both the excision of compromised tissue and the closure of the hernial defect to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical excision: This option only addresses the excision of the skin and does not treat the underlying hernia. Simply excising the umbilical tissue will not resolve the hernia defect or prevent recurrence, making this option inadequate.

 

Option C. Antibiotics: Antibiotics alone are not a definitive treatment for a hernia. While antibiotics may be used if there is an associated infection, they do not resolve the underlying mechanical problem of a hernia.

 

Option D. Incision and drainage: This procedure is appropriate for abscesses and localized infections but not for hernias. There is no indication of an abscess in this scenario; rather, it is a hernia with possible ischemic or gangrenous changes, requiring surgical repair rather than drainage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of complicated umbilical hernias, especially when the hernia becomes irreducible, surgical intervention with umbilical excision and herniorrhaphy is necessary to repair the hernia and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 73-year-old diabetic, hypertensive woman underwent a cardiac biopsy. Her histology image with special stain is as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Restrictive cardiomyopathy

 

Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by abnormal diastolic filling with relatively preserved systolic function. The histology often shows increased myocardial stiffness due to fibrosis, which is evident as diffuse fibrotic deposition within the myocardium. The cardiac muscle appears normal in size or slightly hypertrophic without significant dilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dilated cardiomyopathy: Typically shows dilated heart chambers and significant myocardial thinning with fibrosis, which is not evident in the provided histology image.

 

Option B. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM): Characterized by marked hypertrophy of the myocardium, especially the septum.

 

Option D. Atrial fibrillation: This is primarily an electrical disorder of the heart, typically not diagnosed via myocardial biopsy and does not have a distinctive histopathological appearance related to the rhythm disorder itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In restrictive cardiomyopathy, the key histological feature is myocardial fibrosis leading to stiffening of the heart muscle, which impacts its ability to fill properly during diastole, though systolic function might be preserved.

questions.text: A patient is given a nicotinic receptor antagonist as a muscle relaxant. Which drug is given postoperatively to recover from muscle weakness? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neostigmine

 

For reversal of neuromuscular blockade from non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, the reversal agent of choice is Neostigmine.

 

  • Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that boosts the concentration of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction, thus enhancing muscle contraction.
  • Neostigmine is the drug of choice for reversing the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants postoperatively. By preventing the breakdown of acetylcholine, it counteracts the muscle-relaxing effects of these drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Physostigmine:

 

  • Physostigmine is a reversible cholinesterase inhibitor. It increases the concentration of acetylcholine at nerve endings.
  • Physostigmine is primarily used to treat anticholinergic (atropine-like) drug overdoses. It can cross the blood-brain barrier and is used for central anticholinergic syndromes. It is not typically used for reversing neuromuscular blockade from muscle relaxants.

 

Option C. Carbachol:

 

  • Carbachol is a cholinergic drug that acts as an agonist at both muscarinic and nicotinic receptors.
  • Carbachol is primarily used in ophthalmology to induce miosis or to reduce intraocular pressure. It is not used for reversing neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine:

 

  • Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker. It binds to nicotinic receptors and causes prolonged depolarization, which initially causes muscle fasciculation followed by paralysis.
  • Succinylcholine itself causes muscle paralysis and is used to facilitate intubation during anesthesia induction. It would not be used to reverse muscle relaxation; in fact, it would exacerbate it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neostigmine is the preferred agent for reversing the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants postoperatively.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of recurrent sinusitis presents with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever. A computed tomography (CT) scan was done. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis

 

Involves the contents of the orbit including fat and muscle, often secondary to sinus infections, particularly the ethmoid sinus.

 

Symptoms include painful eye movements, protrusion of the eyeball (proptosis), decreased vision, and fever.

 

This condition can be sight-threatening and requires urgent treatment.

 

  • For the 35-year-old male patient with a history of recurrent sinusitis presenting with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever, the diagnosis of Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is most consistent with the symptoms and the findings on the computed tomography (CT) scan. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preseptal Cellulitis with Sinusitis: Involves the eyelid and skin anterior to the orbital septum, typically without eye protrusion or vision changes.Fever and eyelid swelling are common, but the involvement of the eye as described suggests a deeper infection.

 

Option C. Subperiosteal Abscess: This is an accumulation of pus between the orbit and the periosteum of the orbital bones, typically a complication of orbital cellulitis. It may lead to eye protrusion and restricted eye movements, but it's typically identified on imaging as a distinct abscess rather than generalized infection signs.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: A broad term that can refer to any soft tissue infection but without specifying involvement of the orbital area in relation to the sinuses would be less specific compared to orbital cellulitis with sinusitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent complications such as vision loss, intracranial spread of infection, and other severe outcomes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive male came with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He has skin lesions as shown in the image. Chest x-ray showed multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates. His sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis was negative and he has a low CD4 count. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. HIV with disseminated histoplasmosis

 

In this case, the patient presents with persistent cough, weight loss, and skin lesions. The chest x-ray reveals multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates, and the patient has a low CD4 count. These findings are significant for several reasons:

 

Disseminated histoplasmosis can mimic tuberculosis, especially in HIV-positive patients. It causes disseminated disease with pulmonary involvement (multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates) and skin lesions. The presence of these lesions and a negative sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis further supports histoplasmosis, as this fungal infection is common in immunocompromised individuals with low CD4 counts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HIV with disseminated cryptococcosis: While cryptococcosis can cause lung disease, it more commonly presents with central nervous system involvement, such as meningitis or meningoencephalitis. This patient does not exhibit neurological symptoms, making cryptococcosis less likely.

 

Option C. HIV with molluscum contagiosum: Molluscum contagiosum causes umbilicated papules but does not lead to bilateral nodular infiltrates in the lungs. Thus, this diagnosis is unlikely given the chest x-ray findings.

 

Option D. HIV with tuberculosis: Tuberculosis is a common infection in HIV-positive patients and can present with similar symptoms and radiographic findings. However, the negative sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Disseminated histoplasmosis in HIV-positive patients can mimic tuberculosis, presenting with pulmonary nodular infiltrates and skin lesions, especially in those with low CD4 counts.

questions.text: FISH is used to detect all of the following except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Point mutation

 

FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization) is a cytogenetic technique that allows for the detection of specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. It is particularly useful in identifying chromosomal abnormalities such as translocations, amplifications, deletions, and aneuploidies (such as trisomy or monosomy). These alterations are detectable because they involve large-scale changes in the chromosomal structure or number that can be visualized using fluorescent probes.

 

However, FISH is not suitable for detecting point mutations. Point mutations are changes at the single nucleotide level, which are too small to be detected by this method. Point mutations require techniques that can analyze DNA sequences at a higher resolution, such as PCR-based methods, sequencing, or allele-specific oligonucleotide hybridization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Translocation: FISH can detect translocations, which involve the rearrangement of chromosome segments between nonhomologous chromosomes. This can be visualized by the hybridization pattern of fluorescent probes.

 

Option B. Amplification: FISH is effective in detecting gene amplification, where multiple copies of a particular region of the chromosome are present, resulting in an intense signal from the corresponding fluorescent probe.

 

Option C. Deletion: FISH can identify deletions, including microdeletions, by showing the absence of a fluorescent signal where the DNA sequence is missing from the chromosome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH is a cytogenetic technique used to detect chromosomal-level changes such as translocations, amplifications, and deletions but is not capable of detecting point mutations at the nucleotide level

questions.text: The microorganism demonstrates resistance to meropenem and aminoglycosides, while being susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole. Which microorganism is most likely responsible? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stenotrophomonas maltophila

 

  • Stenotrophomonas maltophila, previously known as Pseudomonas maltophila, is an opportunistic pathogen responsible for wound infections, urinary tract infections, and septicemia.
  • It displays susceptibility to cotrimoxazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Proteus mirabilis:

 

  • Resistant to: Nitrofurantoin, Tetracyclines
  • Susceptible to aminoglycosides, carbapenems, cephalosporins, cotromoxazole, penicillin+ β-lactamase inhibitors.
  • Clinical manifestations: Respiratory infections, especially in cystic fibrosis patients, and opportunistic infections.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

 

  • Known for resistance to multiple antibiotics, but typically not specifically resistant to meropenem.
  • Susceptible to: A wide range of antibiotics, often including aminoglycosides, depending on the strain.
  • Clinical manifestations: Respiratory infections, wound infections, and urinary tract infections.

 

Option D. Acinetobacter baumannii:

 

  • Known for multi-drug resistance, including to carbapenems like meropenem.
  • Susceptibility varies, but generally not as consistently susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate as Stenotrophomonas maltophila.
  • Clinical manifestations: Hospital-acquired infections, such as pneumonia and bloodstream infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stenotrophomonas maltophila is an opportunistic pathogen resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides but susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant is brought to OPD with complaints of cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. Blood investigations reveal total leucocyte count to be >50,000 cells/L. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Azithromycin

 

Neonate with complaints of paroxysm of cough followed by apnea and leucocytosis (>50,000 cells/ L) points to diagnosis of pertussis, for which DOC is Macrolides, i.e., Azithromycin.

 

Pertussis (Whooping Cough)

 

A well appearing young child begins to choke, gasp and flail the extremities with face reddened. Apnea and cyanosis may follow the coughing.

 

 

Infants < 3 months do not display the classic stages of whooping cough. Catarrhal phase is usually unnoticed.

 

Treatment – Macrolides

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin: This antibiotic is not effective against Bordetella pertussis and is not used for the treatment of pertussis.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole: This antibiotic is an alternative treatment for pertussis in patients who cannot tolerate macrolides but is not the first-line therapy.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: This antibiotic is not typically used for the treatment of pertussis and is not considered the first-line treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For infants presenting with pertussis (whooping cough), characterized by paroxysmal cough and elevated leukocyte count, the drug of choice is azithromycin.

questions.text: What is the most common complication of ERCP? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pancreatitis

 

Many complications can occur with Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), a procedure used to diagnose and treat conditions of the bile ducts and pancreatic duct. 

 

This is the inflammation of the pancreas and is the most common complication of ERCP seen in 1-3% patients. It can occur due to irritation or injury to the pancreas during the procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal perforation: This is a serious but less common complication of ERCP. It can occur when the endoscope or the instruments used during the procedure inadvertently create a hole in the intestinal wall.

 

Option B. Cholangitis: This is an infection of the bile duct system. It can occur if bacteria spread during the procedure, especially if there is an obstruction within the bile ducts that has not been adequately drained.

 

Option C. Hemorrhage: Bleeding can occur, particularly if a sphincterotomy (cutting of the sphincter of Oddi to access the bile duct) is performed. While bleeding is a risk, it is not the most common complication.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Post-ERCP pancreatitis is the most common complication following ERCP, necessitating careful risk assessment and patient monitoring post-procedure.

questions.text: Gibbs free energy curve of an enzyme-catalysed reaction is given by? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A

 

Among the shown options, Gibbs free energy change of an enzyme-catalysed reaction is shown by A.

 

Formation of a product requires the breaking of substrate bonds and conformational change forming a highly unstable transitional state intermediate, it requires energy and this is called Gibbs free energy of activation. In an enzyme-catalysed reaction, this energy barrier is reduced by forming a relatively stable intermediate-enzyme complex. The enzyme provides attachment sites for the substrate and speeds up the rate of reaction. It doesn't change the Gibbs energy of either the substrate or the product. Gibbs free energy curve of an enzyme-catalysed reaction (with no intermediate state) is shown in the image given below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: All the reactions have a transition state, but not all reactions have an intermediate state. There are 2 reasons as to why option B

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Transition state intermediate usually has higher energy compared to the substrate or product. Very unusually a dip might be seen like this when the enzyme-intermediate complex is more stable than the product, and the product is not formed.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Every intermediate state is again, always followed by another transition state. Therefore, every reaction, if it has an intermediate state, needs to have two transition states as shown in the image given below. We don't have 2 such transition states in curve B in the question, which makes it an incorrect answer.

 

 

Option C: Free energy change cannot be a straight line. It has to pass through a high energy intermediate state

 

Option D: Transition energy intermediate never has lower energy compared to the product

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gibbs free energy curve of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction is best represented by Curve A, which shows the formation of a transition state and the reduction in activation energy, leading to the production of the final product.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with varicose veins comes to OPD with complaints of eczema over the same region. What is the stage of the clinical classification according to the CEAP guidelines? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C4a

 

  • The descriptive CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classification for chronic venous disorders is as follows:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C2:

 

  • Description: Varicose veins without any additional skin changes or complications.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, which indicates a more advanced stage than C2.

 

Option B. C3:

 

  • Description: Presence of oedema without skin changes.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, not just oedema.

 

Option D. C4b:

 

  • Description: Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche.
  • Why Incorrect: The patient has eczema, which is classified under C4a, not the more severe skin changes seen in C4b.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • According to the CEAP classification for chronic venous disorders, the presence of eczema or pigmentation in a patient with varicose veins is classified as stage C4a.

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin acts by interfering with EF-2 function? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diphtheria

 

Explanation:

 

Diphtheria toxin inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), blocking its function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clostridium: Produces toxins, but they do not target EF-2.

 

Option C. Bacillus: Associated with different toxins not affecting EF-2.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera toxin affecting intestinal secretion, not EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria toxin uniquely targets EF-2, crucial for understanding its mechanism of action in causing disease by inhibiting protein synthesis.

questions.text: A vegan lady came with features of anemia. She is likely to have deficiency of: (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

 

Explanation:

 

Vegans, who follow a diet that excludes all animal products, are at a higher risk of developing vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is primarily found in animal-derived foods such as meat, dairy products, and eggs. Since vegans do not consume these foods, they are prone to developing vitamin B12 deficiency, which can lead to anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D deficiency is not specifically related to a vegan diet. While vegans may need to supplement vitamin D from non-animal sources, the question does not provide enough information to suggest that this is the likely deficiency.

 

Option C. Vitamin A deficiency is also not directly related to a vegan diet. Vegans can obtain sufficient vitamin A from plant-based sources such as leafy green vegetables, carrots, and sweet potatoes.

 

Option D. Vitamin C deficiency is unlikely in a vegan diet, as many fruits and vegetables are rich sources of vitamin C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vegans are at a higher risk of developing vitamin B12 deficiency, which can lead to anemia, as vitamin B12 is primarily found in animal-derived foods.

questions.text: What is the amount of milk given to term baby in first 24 hours after delivery? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 60ml/kg


The recommended amount of milk (or fluid) to be given to a term newborn in the first 24 hours after birth is 60 ml per kg of body weight. This guideline ensures that the newborn receives an adequate amount of fluid to meet its nutritional and hydration needs during the initial adaptation period after birth.

 

Educational Objective:


The appropriate amount of milk or fluid to be given to a term baby in the first 24 hours after delivery is 60 ml per kg of body weight.

choices.text: Teriparatide can be given along with bisphosphonates.
Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year
Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day
Oral vitamin D3 is given along with oral calcium

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal female patient with a history of Colle's fracture comes to the outpatient department complaining of lower back pain. After undergoing a bone density test, her T score is found to be -2.5. Which of the following statements about the management of her condition is incorrect? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year

 

This question deals with osteoporotic post-menopausal female, who has a history of fracture as well.

 

Bisphosphonates which act by inhibiting the bone resorption by the osteoclasts form the first line of treatment in this patient. Bisphosphonates are DOC for Osteoporosis (Steroid induced, post-menopausal and due to any reason). These are indicated for 5 years and then a drug holiday of 2-3 years is given to avoid adverse effects (increased risk of bone fractures and osteonecrosis of mandible). These can be repeated for another 5 years after drug holiday.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teriparatide can be given along with bisphosphonates: Teriparatide is a parathyroid hormone analog that stimulates bone formation by increasing osteoblast activity. It is particularly useful in patients with severe osteoporosis and a history of fractures. It can be started before bisphosphonates in certain cases.

 

Option C. Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day: The recommended daily intake of calcium for postmenopausal women is around 1200 mg. This helps maintain bone density and prevent further bone loss.

 

Option D. Oral vitamin D3 is given along with oral calcium: Supplementation with oral vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) along with calcium is essential to ensure proper calcium absorption and to maintain bone health. The recommended dose of vitamin D3 is typically around 800 IU per day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bisphosphonates are recommended for up to 5 years, not just one year, in the treatment of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women.

choices.text: Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg HS for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam 500 mcg one tablet OD for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam ½ mg tablet HS daily

questions.text: As an Indian medical intern, which of the following is the correct format for prescription of alprazolam? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days

 

IMPORTANT POINTS REGARDING PRESCRIPTION WRITING:

 

  • Prescription is invalid without date and signature of the doctor.
  • Drug name should never been written in abbreviation form (e.g. never write PCM for paracetamol).
  • Abbreviations like OD, BD, HS etc should not be used in prescription.
  • Leading zeros should always be mentioned (e.g. 0.5 mg is correct but .5 mg is incorrect)
  • Trail zeros should never be written (e.g. 5 mg is correct but 5.0 is incorrect).
  • Microgram should be written as mcg not as µg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When writing a prescription, always avoid abbreviations for dosage instructions, use clear and complete language, include leading zeros for dosages less than one, and avoid trailing zeros. The correct format ensures clarity and safety for the patient.

questions.text: Treatment of the male partner is needed in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trichomoniasis

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is trichomoniasis. Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. When a female is infected with trichomoniasis, she typically presents with symptoms such as green frothy vaginal discharge.

 

Treatment of the female alone is insufficient because if her male partner is not treated, he can reinfect her. This creates a cycle where the infection is passed back and forth between partners. Therefore, treating both partners is essential to break this cycle and prevent reinfection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is not considered a sexually transmitted disease but is due to an imbalance in the vaginal microflora. Treatment of the male partner is not required.

 

Option B. Herpes genitalis: This is caused by the herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2), which produces grouped vesicles over the genitalia. The virus resides in the sacral ganglia and can reactivate under certain conditions, such as immunosuppression. The best advice for couples during active lesions is abstinence from sexual intercourse, but partner treatment is not typically necessary.

 

 

Option C. Candidiasis: This is also not considered a sexually transmitted disease. It results from an overgrowth of Candida species, commonly due to altered vaginal flora. Treatment of the male partner is not required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of the male partner is essential in cases of trichomoniasis to prevent reinfection and break the cycle of transmission.

questions.text: A newborn presented with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Any of the above

 

Occult spinal dysraphism is a condition where there is a defect in the fusion of midline embryonic neural, vertebral, and mesenchymal structures, and it can be presented in newborns with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. Typically, patients with occult spinal dysraphism have a cutaneous abnormality overlying the lower spine, such as a small dimple, a tuft of hair, or a subcutaneous lipoma. These abnormalities can be a sign of underlying spinal cord abnormalities, and it's important to evaluate them thoroughly to rule out any serious underlying conditions.

 

Spinal dysraphism includes-

 

Open spinal dysraphism: Myelomeningocele, meningocele

Occult spinal dysraphism:

  • Spina bifida occulta
  • Spinal lipoma
  • Dermal sinus
  • Tethered cord
  • Split cord malformation (diastematomyelia)
  • And others
     

 

 

 

The initial investigation is usually ultrasound in the neonate and the best investigation is MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region in a newborn may indicate occult spinal dysraphism, which includes conditions such as spina bifida occulta, spinal lipoma, and dermal sinus, all of which can be signs of underlying spinal abnormalities requiring thorough evaluation, typically starting with ultrasound and definitive imaging with MRI.

questions.text: What is the shelf life of CuT 380 A? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 10 Yrs

 

Shelf life of CuT 380 is 10 yrs (its effectiveness is for 12 years)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shelf-life of IUDs

choices.text: 1000 for mother and 400 for ASHA
1400 for mother and 600 for ASHA
600 for mother and 400 for ASHA
400 for mother and 600 for ASHA

questions.text: In an urban area in the state of Madhya Pradesh, a first-time pregnant woman visits a healthcare facility for her delivery following encouragement from an ASHA worker. What monetary advantages will they obtain under the Janani Suraksha Yojana? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 1000 for mother and 400 for ASHA

 

Under the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), a cash incentive scheme, pregnant women who deliver in healthcare facilities are provided financial assistance. The scheme aims to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery among poor pregnant women.

 

Madhya Pradesh is categorized as a Low Performing State (LPS), the incentives are as follows:

 

  • Mother's Package: ₹1000
  • ASHA's Package: ₹400

 

Educational Objective:  

 

 

(LPS: Low performing states; HPS: High performing states)

 

(LPS include UP, Uttarakhand, MP, Jharkhand, Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, Assam, Jammu & Kashmir, Rajasthan)

questions.text: Identify the edges of the lesion given in the following image: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rolled out and beaded

 

The image depicts a skin lesion with particular features at the edges, likely a basal cell carcinoma on face. 

 

This description fits basal cell carcinoma, where the edges of the lesion often have a rolled, pearly appearance due to the nature of tumor growth beneath the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Everted: Everted edges are turned outward or upward. This can be seen in Squamous cell Ca.

 

Option C. Sloping: Sloping edges gradually incline or decline from the lesion to the surrounding skin, without a distinct border. This can be seen in various skin conditions like healing ulcers but is not typically used to describe basal cell carcinoma.

 

Option D. Punched out: Punched-out edges are very steep, almost as if the tissue has been cut with a sharp object. This is more characteristic of trophic or ischemic ulcers. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When identifying skin lesions, rolled out and beaded edges are characteristic of basal cell carcinoma, a common type of skin cancer often seen in sun-exposed areas of the skin.

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with fatigue, tiredness and cervical lymphadenopathy. The TLC and DLC were normal. No immature cells. A lymph node biopsy was performed which shows diffuse effacement of the Lymph node architecture, cells with an indented nucleus, prominent nucleolus, and are atypical. CD10 and BCL2 are positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Follicular lymphoma

 

The clinical scenario presented here, which includes fatigue, tiredness, and cervical lymphadenopathy with CD10 positive BCL2 positive cells, strongly suggests follicular lymphoma.

 

The most common type of indolent NHL is follicular lymphoma. It usually appears in middle age and affects both men and women equally. The tumour is most likely caused by germinal centre B cells.

 

A (14;18) translocation between the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the BCL2 locus on chromosome 18 is the hallmark of follicular lymphoma.

 

Histologically, at low magnification, a predominantly nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern is observed in involved lymph nodes. Two principal cell types are present in varying proportions: (1) small cells with irregular or cleaved nuclear contours and scant cytoplasm, referred to as centrocytes (small cleaved cells); and (2) larger cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm, referred to as centroblasts.

 

Immunophenotyping - The neoplastic cells closely resemble normal germinal center B cells, expressing CD19, CD20, CD10, surface Ig, and BCL6. CD5 is not expressed. BCL2 is expressed in more than 90% of cases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Burkitt Lymphoma: Typically presents with a high-grade lymphoma and a starry sky pattern on histology. It is associated with c-MYC translocation and does not usually express BCL2.

 

Option C. Mycosis Fungoides: A type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma that presents with skin lesions and does not typically show CD10 or BCL2 positivity.

 

Option D. Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML): Characterized by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL fusion gene) and presents with marked leukocytosis and often splenomegaly, not with lymphadenopathy and histological findings as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular lymphoma is characterized by diffuse effacement of lymph node architecture, cells with indented nuclei and prominent nucleoli, and positive immunophenotyping for CD10 and BCL2. It typically presents in middle-aged individuals with symptoms such as fatigue, tiredness, and lymphadenopathy. The presence of the t(14;18) translocation involving BCL2 is a hallmark of this indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

choices.text: Low mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility
Low mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

questions.text: Which of the following is true about red blood cells in Sickle cell anemia: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

 

In sickle cell anemia, red blood cells (RBCs) have abnormal hemoglobin (HbS) that causes the cells to sickle under low oxygen conditions. These sickled cells are more prone to mechanical damage as they pass through the microcirculation, leading to increased mechanical fragility. However, their osmotic fragility is lower compared to normal RBCs because the sickling and subsequent damage to the cell membrane makes them less prone to osmotic lysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cells exhibit high mechanical fragility due to their abnormal shape and membrane characteristics under stress but display low osmotic fragility because they are less prone to rupture in varying osmotic conditions compared to normal red blood cells.

questions.text: A man complains of difficulty in standing up from a sitting position and scissoring gait was observed in him. Which nerve is damaged in this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Obturator nerve

 

The obturator nerve innervates the adductor muscles of the thigh, such as the adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus, and gracilis muscles. These muscles are responsible for adducting the thigh (bringing it closer to the body's midline). When the obturator nerve is involved, adductor muscles of thigh are getting spasm , which can lead to a scissoring gait, where the legs cross over each other during walking. Additionally, patients may find it difficult to stabilize their lower limbs, which causes problems like standing up from a sitting position.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior gluteal nerve: Damage to this nerve typically causes a Trendelenburg gait, characterized by difficulty maintaining pelvic stability, rather than a scissoring gait.

 

Option B. Inferior gluteal nerve: This nerve innervates the gluteus maximus, which is primarily involved in hip extension. Damage here would cause difficulty in rising from a sitting position but does not typically cause a scissoring gait.

 

Option C. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve innervates the quadriceps, which are responsible for knee extension. Damage to the femoral nerve would cause difficulty in extending the knee but does not explain the scissoring gait pattern.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Involvement of obturator nerve may lead to spam of adductor muscles, causing a scissoring gait and difficulty rising from a sitting position due to the impaired function of the adductor muscles.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is oxygen therapy not useful? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Central respiratory depression

 

Explanation 

 

Oxygen therapy is not beneficial in central respiratory depression, as oxygen therapy will reduce the hypoxic drive to breathe further depressing the respiratory frequency and minute ventilation.



 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Because oxygen therapy can be crucial in severe asthma attacks where it helps alleviate hypoxia.

 

Option B. Acute myocardial infarction: As oxygen therapy is often used to increase oxygen delivery to the heart tissue, reducing ischemic damage during an acute myocardial infarction.

 

Option C. Pulmonary edema: Because oxygen therapy helps improve oxygenation in cases of pulmonary edema, especially if caused by heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxygen therapy is not beneficial in central respiratory depression because it may reduce the hypoxic drive to breathe, potentially further depressing respiratory effort and overall ventilation.

questions.text: Which antiepileptic drug specifically enhances the inactivation phase of voltage-gated slow sodium channels, helping to stabilize hyperexcitable neurons? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lacosamide

 

Explanation:


Lacosamide has a unique mechanism of action among antiepileptic drugs. It selectively enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels. While most sodium channel blocking antiepileptics (like phenytoin, carbamazepine) act on fast sodium channels, lacosamide specifically targets slow sodium channels. This mechanism helps stabilize hyperexcitable neuronal membranes and prevents repetitive neuronal firing.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Phenytoin: Incorrect. While it does act on sodium channels, it primarily blocks fast sodium channels, not slow sodium channels. It acts by promoting the inactive state of these channels.

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: Incorrect. Like phenytoin, it acts primarily on fast sodium channels and also affects calcium channels. It does not specifically target slow sodium channels.

 

Option C. Felbamate: Incorrect. It works primarily as an NMDA receptor antagonist and has no significant effect on sodium channels, either fast or slow.

 

Educational Objective:


Lacosamide uniquely acts by enhancing the slow inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels, distinguishing it from other sodium channel-blocking antiepileptics that act on fast sodium channels.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to the OPD. She had itchy lesions on her arm as shown with a family history of asthma. What could be the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atopic dermatitis

 

  • The image displays scratch marks and excoriations caused by pruritic lesions at a flexural site. The patient has a personal history of chronic and recurrent course, and there is also a family history of atopy, specifically asthma. These findings suggest a diagnosis of atopic dermatitis (AD) or atopic eczema (AE).

 

Atopic dermatitis (AD):

 

  • It is a chronic inflammatory condition that tends to persist or exhibit chronic relapses.
  • In infants, the first site of involvement is often the face.
  • Flexural distribution is observed in both the childhood and adult phases of the condition, while in the infantile phase, extensor distribution is more typical.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  1. Infantile
  2. Childhood
  3. Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected:

 

 

  • Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, often appearing in early childhood.
  • As the condition progresses, the lesions may evolve into excoriated and lichenified areas. Atopic dermatitis is commonly associated with secondary infections and skin dryness.
  • In the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis, the UK refinement of the Hanifin & Rajka criteria is employed.

 

UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema).

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus, three or more of the following
    1. Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
    2. History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
    3. History of a generally dry skin
    4. Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
    5. Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/ forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

 

Clinical features of AD include:

 

  • Dennie-morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge

 

 

Fig: Dennie-morgan fold

 

Complications of AD:

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Seborrheic dermatitis:

 

  • This is a chronic condition that primarily affects sebum-rich areas of the body such as the scalp, face, and central chest.
  • It's characterized by yellowish, greasy scales and underlying erythema as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

  • While it can be itchy, its distribution and features are different from the description given.
  • There is no direct association between seborrheic dermatitis and a family history of asthma.

 

Option C. Allergic contact dermatitis:

  • This results from direct skin contact with allergens. It's an immunological response to a substance the individual has become sensitized to.
  • The lesions would be more correlated with contact to specific allergens, and it's not typically chronic or recurrent unless there is repeated exposure to the same allergen.
  • The distribution would be more in line with areas that contacted the allergen, rather than the typical flexural pattern described.

 

Option D. Erysipelas:

  • Erysipelas is an acute bacterial skin infection, typically caused by Group A Streptococcus.
  • It presents as a well-demarcated, raised, erythematous, and tender skin lesion, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever.
  • This condition is acute, not chronic or recurrent as described in the scenario.
  • There's no association with a family history of asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atopic dermatitis is a chronic, pruritic inflammatory skin disease commonly associated with flexural distribution of eczematous lesions and a family history of atopic conditions, such as asthma.

 

References:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 2 Chapter 41 page no 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 3 Chapter 149 page no 149.21

Online resources:

https://www.jaad.org/article/S0190-9622(13)01095-5/fulltext

Question Level – Intermediate

Question Id-7456 Unique Key-Q3994123

questions.text: Graph of cooling of the body? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sigmoid shaped

 

The cooling of the body after death follows a typical pattern. Initially, there is little to no decrease in temperature for the first hour. After this period, the body temperature decreases steadily until it stabilizes, generally around 20 hours post-mortem. This pattern creates a curve that resembles an inverted "S" shape, which is also known as a sigmoid shape. Both S-shaped and inverted S-shaped curves are referred to as sigmoid shapes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inverted sigmoid shaped: This is a misnomer. The correct term for the cooling pattern is sigmoid shaped, which encompasses both the regular and inverted S shapes.

 

Option C. Parabola: This does not accurately describe the cooling curve of the body.

 

Option D. S shaped: While the curve may resemble an S shape in some interpretations, the term sigmoid shaped is more accurate and preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The graph of cooling of the body is best described as sigmoid shaped, indicating the initial slow cooling followed by a steady decrease and stabilization of temperature. ​​

questions.text: A 32-year-old male needs to be dressed in female lingerie and high heels to feel aroused and have intercourse with a female; he denies any sexual attraction towards males. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transvestic fetishism

 

Transvestic fetishism involves the act of cross-dressing to achieve sexual arousal. In this case, the individual derives sexual excitement from wearing female clothing while engaging in sexual activity with females, which is characteristic of transvestic fetishism. He denies any attraction toward males, which further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gender Dysphoria: Gender dysphoria involves a strong discomfort or distress with one’s assigned gender and a desire to be the opposite gender. There is no evidence in this scenario of dissatisfaction with his gender identity or discomfort with his sexual organs, ruling out gender dysphoria.

 

Option C. Homosexual orientation: Homosexual orientation refers to sexual attraction toward members of the same sex. The individual in this scenario specifically denies any sexual attraction to males, making this diagnosis inappropriate.

 

Option D. Testicular feminization: Testicular feminization, or Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome, is a genetic condition where an individual has a male karyotype (XY) but develops as a female due to insensitivity to androgens. This condition is unrelated to sexual arousal patterns or behaviors, and there is no evidence to support this diagnosis in the given context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transvestic fetishism is characterized by sexual arousal from cross-dressing in individuals who do not have discomfort with their gender identity.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding from the nose, nasal obstruction and difficulty in breathing. He gave the history of bathing in the local pool near his house. On examination, red polypoidal mass with whitish dots on the surface is observed. Based on the history, examination and given histopathological image what would be the diagnosis of this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rhinosporidiosis

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic infection caused by the aquatic organism Rhinosporidium seeberi. It primarily affects mucous membranes, especially in the nasal passages but also the eyes, ears, and occasionally other areas. Patients typically present with polypoidal masses in the nasal area that can cause bleeding, nasal obstruction, and respiratory difficulty. It is commonly associated with exposure to stagnant water.

Histopathology: Characteristic findings include large, thick-walled sporangia containing numerous endospores, as observed in the provided histopathological image.

Other Options: 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma

Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that commonly appears on sun-exposed areas but can occasionally occur near the nasal region. It typically presents as a nodular lesion with a pearly edge and may have telangiectasias but lacks the distinct histopathology of sporangia with endospores.

Histopathology: Microscopically, it shows nests of basaloid cells with palisading nuclei at the periphery.

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, affecting the respiratory tract. It leads to the formation of hard, sclerotic nodules and masses mainly in the nasal passages.

Histopathology: It is characterized by the presence of Mikulicz cells, which are large foam cells containing the bacteria, and a background of chronic inflammatory cells.

Option D. Lupus Vulgaris

Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis presenting typically on the skin with reddish-brown nodules and plaques that can ulcerate over time. It rarely affects the nasal area directly unless there is disseminated cutaneous involvement.

Histopathology: Shows granulomatous inflammation with caseating necrosis typical of tuberculosis.

Educational Objective:

Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients with nasal masses who have a history of contact with stagnant water bodies, presenting with the characteristic polypoidal mass and sporangia on histopathology.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with wounds that aren’t healing properly, diarrhea, alopecia, and dermatitis. This could be due to which nutrient deficiency? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc

 

Explanation:

 

 Zinc deficiency, also known as Acrodermatitis Enteropathica, is characterized by symptoms such as impaired wound healing, diarrhea, alopecia, and dermatitis.

Zinc is crucial for immune function, protein synthesis, wound healing, DNA synthesis, and cell division. A deficiency in zinc disrupts these biological processes, leading to the symptoms mentioned.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin C: Deficiency leads to scurvy, which presents with symptoms like bleeding gums, weakness, and bruising, not primarily with the symptoms listed in the question.

 

Option C. Niacin: Deficiency results in pellagra, characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, and eventually death, but does not typically include alopecia as a primary symptom.

 

Option D. Magnesium: Deficiency can cause neurological and muscular symptoms, such as tremors and muscle spasms, which are not mentioned in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency should be considered in patients presenting with a combination of diarrhea, impaired wound healing, alopecia, and dermatitis.

questions.text: A patient with a history of diabetes mellitus presents with heart failure characterized by a reduced ejection fraction and low urine output. Which of the following anti-diabetic medications has been recently approved for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, and may also improve diuresis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Empagliflozin

 

Empagliflozin is a sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor that not only improves glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes but also has cardiovascular benefits. Recent clinical trials have shown that empagliflozin is effective in reducing the risk of cardiovascular death and hospitalization for heart failure in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), regardless of the presence or absence of diabetes. The diuretic effect of SGLT2 inhibitors, leading to increased urine output, may also contribute to the clinical benefit in heart failure patients by reducing fluid overload.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor used to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 2 diabetes, with no direct indication for heart failure.

 

Option C. Rosiglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that has been associated with fluid retention and is not indicated for patients with heart failure.

 

Option D. Insulin degludec is a long-acting insulin used to control high blood sugar in diabetes but does not have an indication for heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Empagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is approved for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and provides cardiovascular benefits, including increased diuresis, which can help manage fluid overload in heart failure patients.

questions.text: Congenital lactic acidosis is due to the defect of: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pyruvate dehydrogenase

 

Congenital lactic acidosis occurs when there is an accumulation of lactic acid in the body from birth, often due to a metabolic defect. In normal metabolism, glucose is converted to pyruvate through glycolysis. Under aerobic conditions, pyruvate is transported into the mitochondria, where it is converted into acetyl-CoA by the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase. Acetyl-CoA then enters the Krebs cycle to produce energy in the form of ATP.

 

When there is a deficiency or defect in the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme, pyruvate cannot be converted to acetyl-CoA. As a result, pyruvate accumulates and is instead converted to lactate, leading to lactic acidosis. Since this condition is present from birth, it is termed congenital lactic acidosis. Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is one of the key causes of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transketolase: This enzyme plays a role in the pentose phosphate pathway (also known as the hexose monophosphate shunt) and is not directly involved in the conversion of pyruvate or the production of lactic acid. Defects in transketolase do not lead to congenital lactic acidosis.

 

Option B. Branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase: This enzyme is involved in the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids and its deficiency causes Maple Syrup Urine Disease, not congenital lactic acidosis. It is unrelated to pyruvate metabolism.

 

Option C. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of the Krebs cycle, catalyzing the conversion of isocitrate to alpha-ketoglutarate. While it is involved in cellular respiration, defects in this enzyme are not responsible for congenital lactic acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is a key cause of congenital lactic acidosis, as it prevents the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, leading to an accumulation of lactic acid.

questions.text: A young female presented with flank pain, smoky urine and edema. Her urine examination revealed the presence of 20 RBCs/HPF with dysmorphic red cells. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis

 

The presence of dysmorphic red cells in the urine and smoky-colored urine indicates glomerular hematuria, which is characteristic of glomerulonephritis. Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a common cause of glomerulonephritis, especially in children and young adults. It typically follows a streptococcal infection (such as pharyngitis or impetigo) by 1-3 weeks and presents with symptoms like hematuria, edema, and hypertension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nephrolithiasis: Kidney stones usually cause hematuria with non-dysmorphic red cells and flank pain but not typically associated with smoky urine or dysmorphic RBCs.

 

Option C. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: This condition can cause proteinuria and hematuria but is less likely to present acutely with the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Minimal change disease: This condition primarily causes nephrotic syndrome with proteinuria and edema but not usually hematuria with dysmorphic red cells.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Presence of dysmorphic red cells and smoky urine is suggestive of glomerulonephritis. Out of the given options, post streptococcal glomerulonephritis is the most important condition associated with glomerulonephritis.
